list-item.p: Geographic distribution: Risk varies with country and environment (e.g., urban or rural, mountains or coastal plains). Although malaria is the most common infection diagnosed in travelers returned from sub-Saharan Africa, dengue is more prevalent in travelers returning from Southeast Asia and enteric fever from southcentral Asia (see Table 150.1).

Incubation period: Most travelers become symptomatic within 21 days of exposure, with the majority presenting within 1 month of return. However, some pathogens have a much longer incubation period (e.g., Plasmodium vivax and tuberculosis); patients can present months or, rarely, years later ( Table 150.2 ).
